Title.evidence: Effects of ESRT on Stress and Cognitive Function in PGY-1 Trainees: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Two single-institution randomised clinical trials were conducted.

Participants.evidence: Participants were first-year surgical (ESRT-1, n = 44) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2, n = 45) residents.

Intervention.evidence: ESRT-1 involved 8 weekly 2-hour classes, while ESRT-2 involved 6 weekly 90-minute classes.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effects of an iteratively adapted MBI, ESRT, on perceived stress, executive cognitive function, psychosocial well-being, and pro-inflammatory gene expression in surgical and mixed specialty PGY-1 trainees.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was perceived stress, and the secondary outcome was executive function.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment ensured.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were first-year surgical (ESRT-1, n = 44) and mixed specialty (ESRT-2, n = 45) residents.

Result_Outcome.evidence: ESRT-1 participants showed improved executive function and mindfulness scores, while ESRT-2 participants had lower emotional exhaustion and depersonalization scores at follow-up.
